column1: Data Cleaning documentation
Project Title: Case study : How does a bike-share navigate speedy success?
Prepared By: Ayesha Fathima
Introduction
This document details the data cleaning procedures applied to the divya_trip_data.csv which consist of 12 months data of the year 2023 .
The goal was to prepare the data for analysis by addressing missing values, standardizing formats, and correcting inconsistencies.
Data Source
The data was sourced from a publicly available data through Google Search, stored in divya_trip_data.csv.
I'll share all 12 months dataset in csv format.
Data Cleaning Steps
Removal of Blank rows
Method Used:
Go To Dialogue box
Data Manipulation
New Columns Added:
1. day_of_week : To extract each day of week from the date column provided in integer form
2. Average_ride_duration : To retrieve the duration of ride by subtractig the start and end time of bike ride.
Standardizing format:

column2: Standardizing datetime column to only time format "HH:MM:SS"
Purpose: To identify peak hours during the day

column1: Data Quality Check:
Data Type Validation: All columns confirmed to have correct data types.
Missing Values: No missing values remain.
Consistency: All categorical columns verified for consistent and valid entries.
Note: All the above steps were performed to clean each month data from Jan to Dec
The datsets were imported in MYSQL for further analysis
SQL Script Details
Combining Monthly Datasets into a Single Column:
To merge 12 separate monthly datasets into a single unified dataset. Each dataset represents one month of data, with identical column structures.
The goal was to combine these datasets into one table, adding a new column to indicate the month associated with each record.
Below is the code used;

column2: -- Insert data from each month table
SELECT 'jan' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM jan
SELECT 'feb' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM feb
SELECT 'march' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM march
SELECT 'apr' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week, ride_length FROM apr
SELECT 'may' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM may
SELECT 'june' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM june
SELECT 'july' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM july
SELECT 'aug' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM aug
SELECT 'sep' AS month, ride_id, rideable_type,start_lat,start_lng,end_lat,end_lng,member_casual,day_of_week,ride_length FROM sep

column1: Resulting Structure:
Columns: The final dataset includes all original columns from the monthly datasets, plus an additional month column.
Data Integrity: All records from the 12 monthly datasets are now consolidated into a single dataset with the month column clearly identifying the source month.
